title: What will be the combined U.S. domestic theater box office gross for June, July, and August 2021?
possible_answers: More than $500 million but less than $1 billion
preds:
As of Aug 22, 2021 at $1.241B
Expected at $1.372B per simple extrapolation.
Look back at this on Aug. 22 and decide.
Gonna have to check that Paw Patrol movie later on (released within last day) but there's practically not enough time left.
Oops. This one is a lesson to update my forecasts more often. In retrospect, I think a lot of us were surprised at how many people went to the movies this summer. I certainly was.
Paw Patrol movie is my primary uncertainty here.

980m in June and July leaving 770m to get to 1.75bn.
770m over 31 days is an average of 24m per day
First 10 days Aug are 125m at an average of 12.5m per day.
No way going to get to 1.75bn, so leaving forecast as is
August failing to climb even with The Suicide Squad released.
Officially north of one billion. Would need $700 non in next 24 days to get to the upper threshold, which isn’t going to happen. Affirming forecast.

980m in June and July
Nearly 600m in July.  This was 50pc of 2019.
If august is 50pc of August 2019 this is 600m, which is close would leave us 150m below 1.75bn
Cinema going is increasing.  But so is COVID.
Aug 21 needs to 90pc of Aug 19 to beat 1.75bn.  Possible, but looks hard.  So staying with my full on 100pc forecast

Oops. Just reread question. Threshold is 1.75bn. No chance of that. July looks like it will be about 500m, bringing June and July to a total of 900m This leaves 850m to get to 1.75bn. 
August 19 has 800m so this was the max max that can be reached July was less than half July 19 so if Augusta goes the same way this is 400m. Not likely to get to 1.75bn

July looks like it will be about 500m, bringing June and July to a total of 900m This leaves 600m to get to 1.5bn. 
August 19 has 800m so this was the max max that can be reached July was less than half July 19 so if Augusta goes the same way this is 400m. Under the 1.5bn Going to leave a small pc on the over 1.5bn just in case something crazy happens. I’ve not looks to see if there are lots of unusual August releases or not.
Uptick in delta looks like it will more or less close this out in bucket 4

August would need to be close to double the July total. July had some strong returns in F9 and Black Widow, and while there are a couple releases remaining, the odds like very low (less than 1 in 100) that you could literally double that. On top of everything, increased acceleration of COVID means it's not a pure "return to normal" situation: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-27/nyc-la-among-big-cities-joining-rural-states-in-cdc-mask-zone?srnd=premium&sref=i2Bc5OtW

Would need $883 in next 37 days, which is an average of  roughly $23 per day. We’re barely hitting that this past weekend, so it’s clear that you’d need a massive new series of releases to get there and the pipeline doesn’t look that strong.

If today’s numbers are to be believed, we’re at 422 for July which brings the summer total to 821. That means we need 929 million to get to 1.75 billion, and there are 6 weekends to do that. Requires a weekend average of 154 million which will be hard to get given that the biggest hits of the summer (F9 and Black Widow) are probably behind us. But not impossible. Keeping a 10% probability.

Blowout weekend. First half of summer is done and you’re at 750 million. Would need a pretty significant pickup in back half to get to 1.75 but I think crowd is still
Low on it.
Box office in July significantly vastly exceeding historical averages - at this point going over 1 billion is way more likely than it staying under

Removed from 500M to 1B due to a subjectively unreasonable drop that has to occur with the remaining months. Still think 1.75B is doable and ideal but is seriously threatened due to the rising COVID situation which also puts bin 4 more probable.

If you have to wear a mask, probably don't want to go to the movies. This is only LA, but slightly concerning: https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-07-15/l-a-county-will-require-masks-indoors-amid-covid-19-surge.  The reality is that the if you even have just half the rate of the first half of the summer you get to $1 billion, and that would be massively below pre-pandemic levels.
Normally I would disregard bin 5 but you must remember that we are currently rebounding from pandemic lows and future grosses could be way more than current baselines.

Coming down on bucket 5 due to the lack of crowd apatite for the next 6 weeks to deliver ~160M in takings per week over the next 7 weeks. But there's little chance of the people suddenly being barred from cinema going, so there's a good chance this is going over $1B by the end of the month.
Wow, 1st weekend and Black Widow dethrones F9.  Apparently streaming may not be hurting box office as much as potentially anticipated.  Now Space Jam is on deck.  This puts $1.75B+ back in play.
Update for box office in June and July

Looking more into box office numbers convinced me to revise up substantially.
[F9](https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl192906753/) has grossed 137M just in the first 2 weeks it's been out
[Black Widow](https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl2122089985/) grossed 40M just in the first day, so will likely be at >150M just in the first 2 weeks it's been out
July will likely be at least 500M, which means August only needs 100M for the question to resolve at >1B total.

Early indication is that we're going to go close to my prediction of $250M in July takings by mid next week. https://www.businessinsider.com/black-widow-to-beat-f9-opening-weekend-box-office-projections-2021-7?r=AU&IR=T
Raising up as of new numbers coming in https://www.boxofficemojo.com/month/by-year/2021/?grossesOption=calendarGrosses

I'm not taking the (comparatively) underwhelming July 4th numbers to significantly shift numbers downward. IMO, given the last 18 months, when special occasions come around spending time indoors, watching a screen is going to get dropped as an activity. Rather than being a bell-weather, long weekends are probably going to see only slight bumps in viewership, rather than "standard" weekends, and release weekends will be a bigger factor in attendance.  I guess watch for Black Widow's release, if I'm right, we should have over $250M in July takings by next week, and if I'm wrong, I'll blame the Disney+'s day after release and ask you to look for Space Jam as a proxy for my prediction.
Downward revision after 4th of July numbers

August is generally ~2/3 of June/July. So assuming no change in underlying level, we'd get 400+400+400*(2/3) = 1.07B. Seems likely to either be at or above this number unless COVID gets really bad to a level that slows down re-opening / people's comfort levels. Seems fairly unlikely but not impossible.
Just a little adjustment, F9 and AQP2 are not the biggest titles released this season. After $400M takings in June, July is a good chance to break $600M.

I am not entirely sure why I have been so conservative about this but with June at 399m, and Black Widow and Space Jam to come in July, 1bn doesn't seem like such a high hurdle, assuming the delta variant does not cause major issues.

my hope is someone will actually make a movie worth watching. And no flashing tech in the theatre. No cell phones no tech in the movie theaters. Make a movie theatre faraday cage that would be cool. Impervious to satellite gama rays brainwashing you to be broke back mountain or princess leya. How bout a real 007 movie where an American child escapes his kidnappers because they wanted his hair and ends up in SAS training and kills assholes around the world until he’s captured and placed in a CIA child’s prison where he escapes to drugged and brainwashed to be CIA wetworks but never takes showers.
Not really sure if I think it will hit $1.75 or not, but can't pass up the opportunity to overweight crowd by ~30% in both of the only buckets where I think it'll end up.

My logic here is that there is already $388M in the bank. So, the question is now "will there be at least $612M box office gross in July and August?" With a baseline assumption that July will exceed June due to the release of Black Widow, the chances of some derailing event or policy seem slim to me. Therefore, I'm confident we will see more than $1B. The biggest question mark is whether we are seeing an upward trend in movie going generally or if we are seeing fanatics drawn to big releases. The answer to that question is going to be difficult to tease out over the next few weeks.

June 2021 closed with $388,790,878 gross from 78  releases (up to 4,179 theaters) and F9: The Fast Saga transpiring as the #1 release with a gross of $83,143,285 within just five days. In such circumstance, F9 could probably add some 125mn USD more over summer, resulting in a oversimplified box office gross total June through August 2021 of 1.1 to 1.2bn USD.
The big questions are:
/will the CDCs close indoor venues, enforce mask mandates even for the fully vaccinated, like important minds such as Dr. Fauci suggest, when the DELTA variant fully impacts?
/will "Black Widow" (out: 09 July) and other "wide releases" repeat the success of F9, and how many other releases are there about to come which potentially break 100mn USD each? To date, I only see two: Space Jam: A New Legacy (16 July)  Jungle Cruise (30 July)
Pushing upward given the success of F9 and the expected performance of Black Widow.

@SE_Meyer, initial estimate for opening weekend is $70M for F9. https://www.boxofficemojo.com/month/june/2021/?ref_=bo_my_table_1 I need to put some thought into how the release of Black Widow on Disney+ premium the day after it's out in cinemas will impact things before shifting my position.
Banger of a weekend - up to 367 million for month of June.

500m is 166m per month
1bn is 333m per month May = 209m
June = 368m so far with 3 days to go, likely quite high, but not as high as this weekend, so let’s say another 40m gets to 400m
July = expect peak around July 4 To get to 1m from 400m both July and August need to be over 300m which seems very likely now that people are clearly going back to the cinema.  Plus I guess some delayed block busters and summer coming too. Totally underestimated before, going for 1bn fairly likely.

If July and August can keep pace with June, then we're on pace for a billion. Several states weren't fully open in June and so that perspective makes me think greater than 50% odds you get to $1 billion. Getting over 1.75 billion seems pretty extreme as you'd need back to back $750 million months when the lineup doesn't look that strong.  From a granular perspective, I see 4 potential big releases to watch. If each nets $200 million, then we're easily over the billion mark, but that's a big "if." 1. Black Widow, which is an MCU movie. The median MCU domestic box office is $330 million and Black Widow is projected to be at $270 billion: https://www.forbes.com/sites/travisbean/2020/04/24/all-23-marvel-cinematic-universe-films-ranked-at-the-box-office-including-black-widow/?sh=2f6ecb9e494e 2. Hotel Transylvania: Transformation. The 4th in a series, and the 3rd one grossed $500 million worldwide (not sure on domestic): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotel_Transylvania#:~:text=The%20films%20have%20received%20mixed,released%20on%20October%201%2C%202021. 3. Snake Eyes, GI Joe - $175 million budget.  4.Suicide Squad sequel (grossed $325 million in 2016): https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2021/06/22/will-james-gunns-the-suicide-squad-be-a-late-summer-smash-or-an-unrequested-sequel/?sh=3732ad831190 However, other than that the lineup does not look great this summer: https://www.vox.com/22419048/summer-movies-2021-blockbusters-streaming. All told, I think you have block busters that can likely pull in $600 million and then a tail of movies good for (and I'm really making this up), call it $150 million, and so you have your 650 plus the 334 so far and you're in the 1-1.75 billion category.
I'm almost convinced of bin 4, but held back because of the Delta variant.

500m is 166m per month
1bn is 333m per month May = 209m
June = 250m so far, on track for about 275m
July = expect peak around July 4. If June is 285m then need 715m over July and Aug which is average 357m per month I assume July will be over 300m with July 4 holiday and Aug with summer holidays may maintain, but not sure both months will get us over 350m.  It’s a large step up from June. Will definitely get over 500m though.

"F9" banked $136M in opening weekend in China $200M to date (1). I've shifted heavier into bucket 4 after discovering this and may drop bucket 3 quite low, if the domestic market can show similar enthusiasm of the return of the AAA blockbuster to screens, release is this week.  1. https://www.boxofficemojo.com/title/tt5433138/

The spread of the Delta variant in the US (10% of new cases under surveillance as of 05 June 2021) is likely to erase parts of the gross of the last week in July and impact most of the August releases and business in one way or another.
Movie theaters are indoor "congregate spaces" and thus pose a risk in general, which will be exacerbated by the natural properties of Delta. Wearing a KN95 mask for two hours or more, on the other hand, isn't fun either, so my best guess is, those who are really into fresh hollywood releases are likely going to turn away from theaters and watch everything on their home screens via stream.

Incomplete month-to-date gross is about 170mn USD for the first half of June 2021. The second weekend was far less active than the first one. I wonder if this is the result of the absense of an interesating release equivalent to "In a quiet place II" only, or if going to the movies at the moment has lost the appeal. However, a pattern seems to be confirmed for generalization that a new release must the bulk of the money within the first three weeks after release. Projecting forwards from H1 of June, the gross would come out between 1.05bn USD and 1.1bn USD (on the high end due to major releases yet to come), however, also considering the results of weekend 2 as the more recent trend (WE2) puts more weight on a scenario of 900mn USD to 1.0bn USD. On average, 950mn USD seems reasonable, but it may well become a limit case straight on the edge between bin 3 and bin 4.

Probably the movie theaters have to compete for visitors at the moment with livecasts of important sports events (Stanley Cup, NBA Championship). Which brings me to my expectation for late summer: so far I have neglected any preference of US viewers for European football (soccer: UEFA EURO 2020) or the 2020 Tokyo Summer Olympics. If the past weekend is significant, then "In a Quiet Place II" will stay ranked #1 by box office at least until mid-August, since people will be busy doing or consuming other things. Successful movies really may score less box office gross on average than previously thought. Kids will be in summer camps again where applicable, that is probably why "In the Heights" and "Peter Rabbit 2: The Runaway" went off relatively poorly.

Two major releases from the 04 June 2021 weekend and their "Opening" box office gross:
/"The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It"
3,102 theaters
$24,104,332 (04 - 06 June 2021)
https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl3842475521/?ref_=bo_sd_table_4 /"Spirit Untamed"
3,211 theaters 
$6,101,050 (04 - 06 June 2021)
https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl2450228737/?ref_=bo_sd_table_9 Five other releases (among them "Witnesses"	$206,990	90 theaters; "Undine"	$27,065	56 theaters) had little theater coverage, thus little box office gross and are almost neglegible. For comparison, "Spiral" (released 14 May 2021, 2,811 theaters, "Opening" $8,750,034, latest: $21,923,977 (as of 07 June 2021)), as an supposed average 2021 summer release was able to raise its total by 150% after opening within three weeks, latest daily increase <1% of total.
https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl1745389057/?ref_=bo_sd_table_5 Combining the above mentioned two releases: 30,205,382USD
Projection after three weeks: 30,205,382USD*2.5 ~75.5mn USD.
There are 12 weekends remaining until 29 August 2021: 906.2mn USD for new releases (two successful per weekend, 24 in total) only.
This projection does not include very successful blockbusters (under pandemic conditions, "Opening" of > 100mn USD) and incremental gross after three weeks of screening either. The buffer to the third bin's upper bounds thus looks a bit slim, therefore I adjust towards >1.00bn USD.

Maintaining my position this is going to come back high, it's 1 weekend in and almost $100M grossed.  Given the release schedule, this could push $1B by the end of July, if the sequel to "A Quiet Place" can gross $90M over 2 weekends, I can see the 4-5 AAA blockbusters that have maintained their Jun/Jul/Aug release dates could comfortably pull in over $200M each.

In A Quiet Place II  (#1:  ~31mn USD between 01 and 06 June 2021) and Cruella (#2:  ~16.5mn USD between 01 and 06 June 2021) grossed about 5% of the expected maximum outcome of this question in about 6% of the time line.
If there aren't any bigger gaps between future popular releases, the result may come close to or even exceed 1bn USD. I will adjust accordingly.
Slight upward correction based on figures in May and decreasing uncertainty over summer

500m is 166m per month
1bn is 333m per month May = 209m
June 23m in 4days so roughly 5m per day
5x30 = 150m, but this is low.  Think will be around may levels.

The recent figures from May are quite informative: According to  https://www.boxofficemojo.com/season/?ref_=bo_nb_hl_secondarytab their summer season 2021 lasts from 07 May 2021 through 06 September 2021, thus extended by roughly one month.
The month of May 2021 will slightly underestimate the summer performance due to a lack of releases and a remainder of above-average restrictions. However,
/a top movie this year is played in more than 3,700 theaters (which could indicate that 20% of theaters are out of business permanently) and is able to rake 57mn USD in a Fri-to-Mon first weekend performance, a holiday included.
https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl2819065345/?ref_=bo_sl_table_1
/it is striking how quick the box office results decline: -35% on Day 2 and -50% on Day 3 versus debut day. It points to a large interest from a certain cinema-keen target group, but the broad interest of the young and active population with a high purchase power (at least before the pandemic...), who used to go to the movies as a pastime has not recovered yet.
/a single top release can make up for roughly up to  40% of box office results (57,000,000 versus a cumulative gross of 186,332,947 from 70 releases in total so far this summer season) which means 20 times its proportionate share. My view is that this straddle of very good versus average or bad results has widened because of the pandemic and is likely to remain important throughout the pandemic year 2021, despite vaccination. There will be a few must-see releases that will attract a high number of viewers, while the rest will be more or less ignored. Thus, the main factor driving a high gross appears to be interesting releases.
/extrapolation from the May rump figures to a full month May results a gross of roughly 240mn USD. Given that May might still be the weakest of the summer months, and given the slight under-estimation due to restrictions in place as mentioned above (or felt by the public), a normal summer month in 2021 could produce a gross result of 300mn USD under current conditions.
/a top release in 2021 so far produces only 10% of what it used to be in 2012, 2015, 2018 and 2019 but already exceeds Tenet (2020) by 150%
/a regular summer season brought about 380 releases  per season or 95 per month (bandwidth: 346 in 2011, 425 in 2018 over the past ten years). The 70 releases of May 7th through May 31st indicate a decrease of 20-25% in the number of releases this whole season. The number could thus end at 300 (2020: 86)
/the current gross this summer season is still below what "The Avengers" (2012, 4,349 theaters, 242 days https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl709199361/?ref_=bo_sl_table_10 ) had grossed after three days (04-06 May 2012) alone already. It is to date also only about 4.5 per cent of what an average season totaled between 2011 and 2019.  With regards to the progress being made (new cases, people fully vaccinated,...) and an increasingly normal attitude of the population, the three months of 2021 that will resolve this question could 
/see 300 releases, of which 280 will likely gross 20mn USD or less
/have one or two releases the gross of which exceeds 100mn USD each before the question ends
/end with a total gross that represents 20% of 2019's gross (4.342bn USD), likely a bit higher: between 850- 900mn USD
/will be very dependent on quality and popularity of single releases, and whether the studios are willing to release them to the theaters under (still-) pandemic conditions
/could depend on small details such as sanitizing or mask-wearing requirements during the stay at the theater, which likely impacts the experience of the viewing, and possible future changes in requirements.
/find important releases being scheduled on the labour day weekend and thus outside of the time frame of this question. All this is in line with my previous expectations, yet shifted slightly to the higher end of the scale.

*26-5 adjusmtent for lower than expected box office in May, and for this survey: https://observer.com/2021/05/marvel-black-widow-box-office-covid-19-film-recovery-disney-plus-hbo-max/*
1) establishing base rate: the 2015-2019 average box office gross was around 860 million USD. Variation is significant (2015 = 943 M USD, 2017 = 643 M USD)
2) For decenia now, there has been a slightly rising trend in gross box office. People are buying less but more expensive tickets (partly due to inflation).
3) the impact of competition from streaming thus far was not excessive. Income of streaming services rose over the Covid-19 pandemic, but not excessively.
4) There have been few bankruptcies among cinemas in the U.S. In the years leading up to the pandemic, the number of cinemas was on the rise.
5) Cinemas have been reopening in most states (with allowed capacity ranging from 20% to 100%). This has led to doubling of Gross Box Office in past months, with the income for April back to USD 189 million.
6) Looking at Covid-19 vaccination speed and trend in new infections, we can expect a reopening of most cinemas before or during the summer.
7) month-to-month variation in gross box office (very large) is largely determined by blockbuster releases. This summer looks like a strong summer for blockbusters, including a new Space Jam. Calculation: we expect a slightly below average year, because of limitations in cinemas that are open (especially in June). We expect the bounce-back effect ('haven't been to the cinema in ages') to roughly cancel out the increased Netflix subscriptions, for lack of a better assumption. This means we will predict based on an expected average of 650 million USD, with a 95% confidence interval of 350 m USD.

1) establishing base rate: the 2015-2019 average box office gross was around 860 million USD. Variation is significant (2015 = 943 M USD, 2017 = 643 M USD)
2) For decenia now, there has been a slightly rising trend in gross box office. People are buying less but more expensive tickets (partly due to inflation). 
3) the impact of competition from streaming thus far was not excessive. Income of streaming services rose over the Covid-19 pandemic, but not excessively. 
4) There have been few bankruptcies among cinemas in the U.S. In the years leading up to the pandemic, the number of cinemas was on the rise. 
5) Cinemas have been reopening in most states (with allowed capacity ranging from 20% to 100%). This has led to doubling of Gross Box Office in past months, with the income for April back to USD 189 million. 
6) Looking at Covid-19 vaccination speed and trend in new infections, we can expect a reopening of most cinemas before or during the summer. 
7) month-to-month variation in gross box office (very large) is largely determined by blockbuster releases. This summer looks like a strong summer for blockbusters, including a new Space Jam.  Calculation: we expect a slightly below average year, because of limitations in cinemas that are open (especially in June). We expect the bounce-back effect ('haven't been to the cinema in ages') to roughly cancel out the increased Netflix subscriptions, for lack of a better assumption. This means we will predict based on an expected average of 650 million USD, with a 95% confidence interval of 350 m USD.
May not doing well as I had expected but there is a risk that this summer shoots back up to normal levels which is way off the current scale.
April = 183m.  180 * 3 = 570m. Over next 3 months openings only more likely to go up than down, but not sure will get to double this rate needed to pass 1bn
Forgot to account for combining the three months. I have high hopes.

https://www.boxofficemojo.com/month/by-year/2021/?grossesOption=calendarGrosses&sortDir=asc&sort=interval&ref_=bo_my__resort#table
This says it all. Im also betting that with restrictions easing up, good weather incoming, and people feeling more comfortable going out because of vaccinations, numbers will only continue to rise. I think that America has not lost its love for going to the theater in favor of streaming.

"Godzilla vs. Kong" is pushing $80M in April. Which will deliver around $200M for the month. (1) With release schedule and vaccination progress, it's difficult to believe that we live in a world where Godzilla vs. Kong delivers this level of ticket sales and the summer schedule pales in comparison.  1. https://www.boxofficemojo.com/month/by-year/2021/?grossesOption=calendarGrosses

We are starting to see enough data to make reasonable estimates. There are two factors to consider. First, the ability for releases to draw viewers (around 50% of normal). Second, the volume and quality of releases (around 50% of normal). For now, it seems that the release schedule isn't lining up with the summer time frame of this question. If we start seeing releases that were previously pushed into the fall move back toward the summer, I'd adjust upward. For now, it seems like we are on track for $400-$600M. Oh, and there is still an outside chance that theaters get shut down again.

"Godzilla vs. Kong" raked 80.5mn USD in NA box office gross in three weeks, despite simultaneous streaming start.
Further tendency towards "normal" due to progress in vaccinations, a gross of less than 500mn USD can almost certainly be excluded  at this point in time, if at least a few very popular movies head for debut in the three months of June through August 2021.
It is still unclear how far a beginning fourth wave in the U.S. with involvement of variants of concern (VoC) can still halt reopenings at a large scale, but movie theaters will be eager to go back to business and thus fulfill all safety precaution requirements and stick to the official guidelines when their time has arrived (at least they've had plenty of time for preparations without spectators). https://www.news24.com/fin24/companies/travelandleisure/godzilla-vs-kong-crushes-us-box-office-despite-warner-bros-simultaneous-streaming-offering-20210419
https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/entertainment/1539859-entertainment-news-roundup-oscars-show-reinvented-as-a-movie-godzilla-vs-kong-tops-box-office-again-and-more

Based on my thinking, things would have to be 62% better than the past two months' pace to reach 500M in the given timeframe on average. However, there are at least 2 movies coming within the timeframe that may rack up a lot of money and by a lot I mean billion dollar movies; they may rack up less than 1B because of the restrictions but otherwise are potential 1B caliber movies. For now, I find it hard to believe that we forecast restaurants not to open fully this summer but the theaters may flourish. Then again, we expect the Carnival Cruise to set sail in July. I am torn.

Based on recent trends and the fact we are already at $116,984,649 as of April 18th, movie-going is undergoing a rapid increase (~doubling every month from February->April?). Not sure how many theatres are currently open, how many have closed permanently, etc. but as more of the US population gets vaccinated --> case counts drop, I see this trend continuing for some time. We are nowhere close to the ~$900,000,000 or so average monthly gross pre-pandemic (to be fair, we are unlikely to go back to that normal), so there's plenty of room to go up, if even for a short time as people are itching to go out and do stuff.

Historical data may not be a good source of data to use for this estimation because of covid. I looked at the domestic release schedule, subjectively identified 'blockbusters' that weren't getting simultaneous release on a streaming-service and then averaged the gross totals of previously released similar titles. I also considered the impact of covid on theatre attendance, and used Godzilla vs. King Kong (2021) as a bellwether for attendance under covid.

March 113m.  april already at 87m.  If we have 120m per month this will be 360m  Thresholds per month for top of each bin
Bin 1 : 66m
Bin 2 : 166m
Bin 3 : 333m
Bin 4 : 583m 2019 hovered about 1bn per month !
If we get 50pc capacity then this would give us near bin 3 to 4 threshold
Are cinémas likely to open at 100pc capacity?  Assuming not then going for bin 2 or 3.

"Top Gun: Maverick" is reported to have been pushed to November (from July 2021) by production company Paramount. Many other blockbuster movies in line for summer presentation could follow, since the success of a film is considered too dependent on initial box office returns, and production firms may not be willing to take a risk of spoiling the reputation of very expensive productions by showing under still limited capacity and disadvantageous consitions. This limits total box office gross to 1bn USD or less, with respect to an obvious surge of SARS-CoV-2 infections, stricter protocols under the CDC and the new WH administrations, and a possible fourth wave in the U.S. over summer aggravated by the spread of virus variants.
$113M takings in March and April on track for >$200M

$113M Mar-2021, $54M already by 6-Apr-2021.  I am guessing monthly totals will be $200-$300m per month this summer.  (Usual pre-pandemic was something like $1.2B, so this is still considerably off pace, but I expect less than 1/3 including because movies aren't being released in theaters and people still mostly choosing outdoors, at-home, and social distancing (so occupancy limits). [1] https://www.boxofficemojo.com/month/april/?grossesOption=calendarGrosses
Reallocating most of the 200-500 box to the two latter boxes based on the success of Godzilla vs Kong

Another question I am only forecasting as its part of the a challenge. 
Two basic assumptions:
Low probability of falling below current trend, so 4% below 200
Very low probability we hit early q1 trend of 2020, so 1% above 1.75.

Cinemas are highly likely to re-open during a summer when a substantial proportion of the population will have been vaccinated and virus transmission is generally lower during the summer months. 2019 take was in excess of $3bn. Even if attendances are limited by capacity constraints, I expect demand to be robust, given a backlog of major releases and pent up demand from consumers. Even if capacity is constrained, price rises are likely to compensate for this volume reduction and allow for a total take well in excess of $1.75bn
February numbers are in, and they were worse than I thought they'd be.
Currently a lot of high-budget films are scheduled, so if they hold up, it will likely be right around the cutoff of $1.75B

Assuming these last three days of February 2021 will bring in $4-5 million dollars, that means on average February 2021 will end up being around 5% of the inflation adjusted average of 2017, 2018, and 2019 Februarys. Feb. 2021 will be 6.42% of inflation adjusted Feb. 2020. For Jan 2021 versus 2017,2018, and 2019 it was 6.18% and for 2021 vs. 2020 it was 6.49%, respectively. If I project June, July, and August 2021 by using the Jan and Feb 2021 performance versus 2019-2017, gross revenue comes in at about $185 million. If I use the Jan and Feb 2021 performance versus 2020, my projection comes in at about $215 million.   And this would all be under the assumption that covid/gatherings would be equally restrictive from June-August as it was from Jan-Feb. Also assuming movies would be as limited as they were from Jan-Feb. The Croods is the box office winner of 2021 so far, it's first installment was released in 2013 which was the 14th best performing movie of that year, grossed about $590 million. @MCowley has done a nice job outlining the upcoming releases for this summer.  To get to $500 million, performance would have to be a hair over 15% of what is was from 2019-2017 on average. For $1 billion, just over 30%. And finally for $1.75 billion, a just over 52%.  Currently, about 6.8% of the population is vaccinated [1]. If we assume vaccinations keep at the rate of 1.7 million per day for March and April and then up to 3 million a day for May, plus add in the Johnson & Johnson shots expected, and lets assume only half of those 100 million doses promised by June are delivered/administered to be conservative. That still gets me to almost half the population vaccinated by June 1st. There's a chance we could have herd immunity by sometime this summer [4]. Depends on a lot of factors.  Now I just want to talk about what it would like to do the numbers I'm projecting (and this is the driver of my forecast). To be over $500 million, I think theaters need to be at 15.2% of what they were from 2019-2017. That means for a sold out crowd in 2019, that theater only needs to be 15% full. For $1 billion, 30% full. For 1.75 billion, 53% full. And again, that would be max occupancy. For reference look at the NBA's current occupancy rates for the 14 teams allowing fans [5]. Most are already at 10%. New York is going to allow theaters to re-open and CA is expected to follow suit, they combined have 15% of theaters and are going to be two of the most cautious states overall I'd imagine [6]. If the NBA already has some stadiums 15% full, the only reason I can't see theaters being 15% full at the max by June 1st is something going very wrong with covid (variant or massive vaccine production problem). I will check back in around the end of March, April, and May, but I expect the trendline to steadily tick up.  [1] https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations

[5] https://ca.nba.com/news/which-nba-arenas-will-allow-fans-to-start-the-2020-21-nba-season/1xjxebnff02i3183pybejqkvmf
[6] https://deadline.com/2021/02/cinemark-movie-theaters-california-reopening-covid-19-summer-releases-1234701789/

January 2021 had a box office of 50 million dollars. In a typical year, January is a good average of June July and August.  However, there are still lockdowns affecting many movie theaters especially in very populated states like California and New York. I expect the rate of covid infections to drop off dramatically over this month because it seems to be following the curve of the flu season. Also the rhetoric being put out by the media about the virus changed on exactly the day of Biden's inauguration. It is now no longer doom and gloom and it is now a tone of solving the problem and climbing out of the hole. By May I expect all states to be fully open.  not very well known but very important to recognize with all of this is that the way they are testing people is changing. Florida and Colorado have focused on what the PCR threshold rates of the tests are. The other states are still using PCR tests with too many cycles causing a very large number of false positives. according to the New York times the number false positives could be as high as 90%. This is why the State of Florida which is one of the oldest states in the country is fully open even Disney World and full tourism, with lower covid rates, while California, which is one of the youngest states in the country is still heavily locked down with very high covid rates. It's because the way they have different testing thresholds. Based on press releases from the CDC and WHO, and based on the way this has changed politically now that Biden is in office, I expect more dtates to be more conscious of their PCR testing thresholds. This will bring down the number of cases dramatically which can be explained to the public by immunizations. In short, I expect the fearmongering revolving around the virus to drop off over the spring.  This means that I expect June July and August to have a significantly higher box office than January of this year. However, there will still be some continued hesitation and I think the economy is going to be very poor. https://www.boxofficemojo.com/month/by-year/2021/?grossesOption=calendarGrosses https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/29/health/coronavirus-testing.html
